title: Classic Chinese Fried Rice
subtitle: Traditional Cantonese Recipe
description: A traditional Chinese dish that transforms leftover rice into a delicious meal. The secret to authentic fried rice is using cold, day-old rice which prevents clumping and creates the perfect texture.

cookingSteps.title: Prepare Rice
cookingSteps.instructions: If using freshly cooked rice, spread it on a baking sheet to cool completely. Ideally, use rice that has been refrigerated overnight.

cookingSteps.title: Cook Eggs
cookingSteps.instructions: Heat wok over high heat. Add 1 tbsp oil and swirl to coat. Pour in beaten eggs and scramble quickly until just set but still moist, about 30 seconds. Remove and set aside.

cookingSteps.title: Saut√© Vegetables
cookingSteps.instructions: Add remaining oil to wok. Add diced onion and carrots, stir-frying for about 2 minutes until slightly softened. Add garlic and white parts of green onions, stir-frying for 30 seconds until fragrant.

cookingSteps.title: Add Protein & Rice
cookingSteps.instructions: If using ham or Chinese sausage, add to the wok and stir-fry for 1 minute. Add cold rice to the wok, breaking up any clumps with a spatula. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until heated through.

cookingSteps.title: Season & Combine
cookingSteps.instructions: Drizzle soy sauce and sesame oil over rice. Add white pepper and stir well. Add frozen peas, scrambled eggs, and green parts of green onions. Stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes until well combined and heated through.

cookingSteps.title: Final Adjustments
cookingSteps.instructions: Taste and adjust seasonings as needed, adding salt if necessary. Transfer to a serving dish and garnish with additional sliced green onions if desired.

additionalNotes: Using day-old rice is crucial for authentic fried rice texture. The characteristic 'breath of the wok' flavor comes from cooking quickly over very high heat. This is a Cantonese-style fried rice. Other regional variations might include different seasonings like oyster sauce, fish sauce, or chili paste.
